context.original_query: Query 1: What's the latest news about Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet?

globals.summary_1C: Boeing plans to end F/A-18 Super Hornet production after 2027, despite a recent US Navy $1.3 billion contract for 17 jets (deliveries by Spring 2027). Production will slow from two jets per month to one and a half, with the St. Louis workforce shifting to programs like F-15EX, T-7A, and MQ-25. The contract, funded by Congress in FY22-23, was delayed due to Navy negotiations with Boeing over technical data rights for the Super Hornet and EA-18G Growler, finally resolved in March.

memory.original_query: Query 1: What's the latest news about Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet?
memory.summarizer_summary:
Here's the latest news regarding the Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet:

Boeing is planning to end F/A-18 Super Hornet production after 2027. This is despite a recent US Navy contract worth $1.3 billion for 17 jets, with deliveries expected by Spring 2027. Production will be reduced from two jets per month to one and a half. The workforce in St. Louis will be shifted to other programs such as F-15EX, T-7A, and MQ-25. The contract, which was funded by Congress in FY22-23, faced delays due to Navy negotiations with Boeing over technical data rights for the Super Hornet and EA-18G Growler, but these issues were resolved in March.

summarizer_snapshots.summary_output:
Here's the latest news regarding the Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet:

Boeing is planning to end F/A-18 Super Hornet production after 2027. This is despite a recent US Navy contract worth $1.3 billion for 17 jets, with deliveries expected by Spring 2027. Production will be reduced from two jets per month to one and a half. The workforce in St. Louis will be shifted to other programs such as F-15EX, T-7A, and MQ-25. The contract, which was funded by Congress in FY22-23, faced delays due to Navy negotiations with Boeing over technical data rights for the Super Hornet and EA-18G Growler, but these issues were resolved in March.

session.final_summary: Boeing plans to end F/A-18 Super Hornet production after 2027, despite a recent US Navy $1.3 billion contract for 17 jets (deliveries by Spring 2027). Production will slow from two jets per month to one and a half, with the St. Louis workforce shifting to programs like F-15EX, T-7A, and MQ-25. The contract, funded by Congress in FY22-23, was delayed due to Navy negotiations with Boeing over technical data rights for the Super Hornet and EA-18G Growler, finally resolved in March.
